comment.author: 60894293@N00
comment._content:
In November 1911, Colonel E.Z. Steever was commanding the 4th Cavalry at Ft. Bliss. In 1900 he as a Major in the 3rd Cavalry, Luzon, Philippines, acting as executive officer under Colonel David Wirt. He was summarily forced to retire in 1913 supposely because of poor eyesight. His friend were taken by surprise on this action by the government, especially since a few years before he had commanded the Marksmanship Team for the Army.

His son, Edgar Zell Steever, III, became known for establishing Cadet Corps in Wyoming while being stationed, and later testified before Congress as a 1st Lt. about the benefits of training both high school boys and girls in the military arts. He continued teaching military science in high schools. He later retired as a colonel in the U.S. Army.

comment._content:
On March 8th,1911, President William Howard Taft ordered 20,000 soldiers to patrol the  South border and battleships to Mexican coasts. By number 2194-15 you can locate the photo on the series in 1911, between the months of  March and May.
About this Mr. Taft had a meeting with  Mexican Ambassador Francisco Leon de la Barra explaining the motives of this action (letter of the Ambassador to President Díaz dated on March 9th, 1911).
Dr. Roberto Duarte
